text: Flaske 500ml delt med Rune på Rom 2 Hazelwood Guest House Newton Abbot 28 Apr 17. Mørk amber. Lavt skum som daler sakte. Spotlacing. Grei maltaroma. Smaken skarp malt. Balansert. Nøttepreg i avslutninga.

Caramelo, nueces, regaliz, aromas de frutas maduras. Color cobre con espumosa cabeza blanquecina, un poco de cordón. Cuerpo medio, carbonatación media a suave, textura sedosa. El sabor es caramelo, dulce, afrutado, frutos secos, regaliz. Suave, equilibrado y agradable. Un poco más de cuerpo la haría más agradable.

500ml bottle bought at a local Sainsburys store. Shared with Finn. Good looking in the glass. A finger-thick beige head to a deep mahogany coloured body. Clingy acing. Attractive malt-fruity aromas, herbal hops and caramel. Smooth taste profile of toffee, earth, dark fruits and berries. Roasted malty-fruity finish. Good depth. Perfect night cap (Hotel room in Newton Abbot 28.04.2017).

500 ml bottle. Somerset UK. Pours hazy reddish brown with medium white head that laces. Aroma is cider and yeast, not much fruit. Taste is reasonably sweet with dried fruits, toffee and solid hop bitterness. Decent hop punch on back of throat. Good full mouthfeel from the carbonation with a noticeable alcohol lift. Quite a good balance between hop and malt. Good example of an English strong ale. Nice!

Bottle. Dark ruby/brown with a big foamy head. Lots of lacing. Aroma of english hops and dark fruits. Taste is malts, hops, toffee, caramell, nuts, berries and a layer of cocoa and milk chocolate. Long lasting hoppy bitter finish. Medium carbonation. Creamy. I like it a lot.

From old tasting notes. Hazy reddish brown color. Big rocky tan head. Soft toffe-like malt nose. Robust nutty toasted malt flavor has a distinct dry hop balance. Chewy mouthfeel. Wonderful Belgian lace.

500ml bottle. Dark copper color. Medium size, beige-yellowish head, stays. Woody, grainy, husky, creamy, malty in aroma. Caramel, malts, bit creamy and buttery, husky in taste. Apple seeds and woody tannins in aftertaste. Soft carbonation. Touch of metallic hops too. Very solid brew.
caramel, cereal, toast, butterscotch, ruby-brown, hazy, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, creamy, lively. Very light caramel aroma. Aftertaste is toffee with an air of berries.

Bottle at home in London - sourced from Ocado. Only took me 6.5 years living in the UK to track this one down! Pours clear amber-copper with a creamy, light tan head. Pleasant aroma, ample dried berries, a little toasted toffee, grape leather. Medium sweet flavour with restrained earthy bitterness, stewed fruits, dried berries, further toffee, dry brown bread, toasted leaves. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Well balanced finish, with notes of burnt frackers, toasted caramel, further dried and leathery berries, earthy hops. Rather enjoyable stuff. Drinks well.

Pours a deep hazy brown with a ruby tinge. Sweet malt aroma. Initial crystal malt bite. Fruity flavours too, leading to more sweet light back end malt. Light to mid body. True to form, fruitcake and rum flavours add to palate and mix well with bitterness. Very enjoyable and easy drinking.

From Hipercor. In Ikeas pint glass. Dinner at Antonias house. With sausages + omelette. It has some odd herbal/metallic notes and a noticeable alcohol that at first dissapoints a lot but with time you get used to it and improves

From pint bottle. Pours very dark with a hint of brown color in the light. Small head with fair retention only. Aroma is of wonderful rich maltiness almost reminiscent of a Belgian. Taste is of a rich maltiness but dialed back to drinkable and almost sessionable. Little booze and gas in the finish
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2017 Nice rich malty beer with some dry hops shining through. Tastes of roasted caramel and chestnuts.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2016 Pours mahogany with off white head. Aroma is of caramel, vanilla and roast. Taste is burnt caramel, licorice, fig, smooth toasty malt. Aftertaste is roast and alcohol. I was Surprised by this beer after only rediscovering it recently, all in all pretty decent beer, definitely helped along by its 6.3%abv. As with most bottled, filtered force carbonated beers its a little thin, but acceptable

500ml bottle from Morrisons. Love their Ghost ship so thought I would give this a go. Pours dark brown/mahogany with a small tan head. Nose is really malty, sweet plum, fig and roasted malt. Slightly like a porter, bit of coffee and bitter chocolate. Mouth feel is thick and syrupy and a bit too sweet for me. Taste is toffee, caramel, prunes, licorice and some malty chocolate. Fairly bitter finish. Got to admit first mouthful was a bit unpleasant and it is rather strong, but it grew on me as I got further down the glass.......that might have just been the 6.3% abv though :-) in all seriousness though its a fairly decent brew.

Aroma is fruity and malty with caramel, toffee, bread, yet hoppy with grass and hay. Taste is fruity malty with toffee, biscuit, caramel and bread yet hoppy with grass and hay. Finish is fruity and dry hoppy in good balance.

"Half stout" or "light stout" for me. Pours dark ruby reddish with beige top. Minimal lasing. Aroma is overly dominated by chocolate kind of malt, some roasty robust bitter finish. Taste is sweet with light bitterness. Medium body, creamy/thicky texture, dry dark malts finish. Weird but I wasnt able to catch some fruity, caramel notes as usual in ESA. Properly brewed but it didnt stick with my palate, too monolit profile.

Bottle : 500 ml, Price : 0,89 eur 
Tamsi ruda, skaidri, spalva, kremine puta. Skrudintas salyklas, geras skonis
Bottle. Dark brown color, light tan head. Aroma of roasted chocolated Taste is roasty toffee. Very tasty.

Mahogany. Malt, caramel, dried fruit, and to a lesser degree, spice and chocolate. Sweetish taste and a dry finish with solid bitterness. Full body. Overall, a very good strong ale. Tasty and well-balanced.

12/10/16 bottle at home. Serious ruby beer. Alcohol almost takes over, but it just gets away with it. Malt and hops just shining through. Probably needs some man food to go with this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Almost quady dried fruit nose, lovely malt base, caramel, some toast, some herbal hops, light spiciness. Moderate sweetness with light bitterness. Quite nice

Pours a brown to ruby-red colour with a pale tan coloured head. The aroma is of malt and ethanol. The taste is toffee, malt and a hint of roasted malt that is initially moderately bitter on the palate with some residual sweetness. Overall not a bad beer.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2016 500ml bottle, chilled and poured at home. Very strong alcohol taste which over powers the palate and masks complexity. It went down the kitchen sink. Very disappointing given the reviews.
Aus der Flasche getrunken (Händlerlieferung). Rotbraun im Glas mit mächtiger Schaumkrone. Sehr dominanter Malzkörper (leider!).

Bottle 500ml. Served at room temperature. Pours a burnt ruby brown. Head is good sized, lightly tanned and lasts very well in the glass. Aroma is of (earthy) English hops, caramel, brown rolls, blackberries, oranges, light notes of milk chocolate and hints of coffee. Flavour is a medium earthy hop bitterness with lightly toasted malts, dry biscuit, caramel, nuts, blackberries, brown bread crusts and a dry earthy finish. Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a long dry finish.
Very good. Cask at airport. Dark brown with Ruby highlights. Sweet stone fruit prune, raisins, malt flavor and aroma.

Bottle. Dark brown with ruby, good creamy foam. Aroma: malt, esters with fruit and brandy, caramel, a little butter and hazelnut. Taste: strong maltiness, wine, dried fruits, caramel, butterscotch, pleasant earthy hop bitterness. Good ale.
Bottle at home. Dark reddish brown. Notes of dark fruit, plum, figs, sweet malts. Low carbonation. Dry bitter sweet finish.
500ml bottle from Asda. Pours ruby brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is light, berries, malt, spice. Taste is nicely bitter with a hint of balancing sweetness. Very smooth, great mouthfeel.

Dark ruby beer with soft carbonation and foamy head. Hoppy nose with marmite hints. Light dry biscuity flavour with metallic, strawberry and earthy hints and gentle bitter finish. Generic but passable.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Pretty bland malt aroma. Taste is toasted malts, some hops. Full, creamy mouthfeel. Pretty ok.

500ml bottle. Pours a clear dark brown/ruby with a small off-white head. Fruity malt caramel aroma, also some spice? Taste of caramel malt and dark fruits, some spice and alcohol, bitter hop finish. Very smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2016 Bottle. Ruby red/brown. Nice lively head which lasts several minutes. Nose a little bland and disappointing. Burnt and roasted flavours initially in the mouth with a medium length bitter finish. Wholesome mouthfeel without being claggy. Ok beer. I cant find fruitcake anywhere though....
Licht caramelletje... licht geroosterde moutigheid... weinig carbs.. licht bitter... goeie drinkbaarheid maar niet byzonder

Bottle from Sainsburys, drunk at home. Pleasantly dark brown with a ruby tint. A little bit of tan/cream head rests on top. Caramel, redcurrants and a hint of coffee in the aroma. Really nice for the most part, but has that odd metallic note so prevalent in big-name pasteurised UK bottled beers. Fruity and sweet with a sharp bitter finish. Aftertaste is nicely bitter without being acrid. Medium body. Pretty tasty and quite possibly the best of the supermarket bitters. And better than the cask version, which is rare.

Bottle. Dark brown with ruby hue, thin off white head with medium lacing. Understated aromas of bread yeast, a touch of spice and chocolate. Big caramel malt flavour, touch Christmas pudding and a long spicy and earthy hop finish. Beautifully smooth. Went well with Stilton and Shropshire cheeses. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark red lovely steady head, tasty dark fruity aroma and taste with strong glow and sweet bitter balance. Tasty

Ambrée/rouge, mousse blanche moyenne. Nez malté, biscuit, caramel, gâteau. Bouche légèrement sucrée, pudding et caramel, bel houblonnage sur des houblons herbeux et poivrée, belle amertume, bonne longueur. Le style est sympa, on est vraiment sur une bière typiquement anglaise !
Bottle - Dark red, fairly dense - good frothy off white head, good lacing throughout. Pleasant fruitcake aroma. Good mouthfeel. Strong tasting, fruity but not tart - Nice beer.

0.5l bottle. Clear amber body, huge off-white head. Aroma of toast, orange zest, dates, minimal sulphur and some nutmeg. Taste of toast, plums, caramel, spicy hops, orange zest and some booze. OK beer.

Bottle; pours cola brown with a khaki head; aroma of malt, caramel, and a hint of licorice and dark fruits; taste is sweet with caramel, licorice, and a touch of dark fruits; finish is slight wet with a hint of bitterness; good beer
*Old rating from 2012.  Nette, karamelliges Bier. Schöne Ale-Note, tief. Dunkle Früchte, dunkles Malz. Dickflüssig-caramellig im Nachgeschmack mit moderater Herbe. Lecker!

L:
-pours a clear copper-ruby with a big,frothy,offwhite head
-low to medium carbonation visible
S:
-spicy,herbal,raisins,strawberries,ch syrup,slight coffee,nuttytoasty finish
-medium to high bitterniss for the style
F:
-medium carbonation
-medium body
O:
Very spicy English Strong Ale.
Pretty good overall
Appearance between amber and dark brown and smells better than its taste not that much good beer

Taste is sweet honey or vanilla, notes of tangy fruit detected.
Amber brown and clear. tan head, Medium lite body.

Bottle 500ml. Poured into a nonic pint glass. Initially served too cold so aroma was suppressed. When it warmed up a little, the aroma was soft but smelled a little like fruitcake with brandy - but far more subtle. Very nice. Poured a deep ruby red / chestnut colour. Tight cream coloured foam, which was about a finger width and held nicely leaving lacing all the way down the glass. Fairly mild sweetness but full tasting. Silky, velvety smooth palate. Short to medium finish with the fruitcake flavour coming in again at the finish, followed by a hint of alcohol which adds to the boozy fruitcake feel. 
Definitely needs to be at the right temperature to appreciate properly. Didnt get half of what Ive written during the first half of the drink and it improved 500% as it warmed up. 
This is a must have repeat for me. Awesome beer. Wow!
Ciemnobursztynowe z biala piana ktora szybko znika. Slodowe z ciezkim posmakiem alkoholu. Owoce rodzynki. Calkiem calkiem
Bottle from Waitrose. Pours dark brown with deep creamy head, which leaves significant lacing. Aroma toasty with chestnuts and malt loaf. Taste rich with bitter coffee, pine nuts and macadamia.
Aroma- Chocolate and hazlenuts. Appearance- Dark chestnut, clear with off-white foam. Taste- Heavy but quite sweet. Palate- Full bodied Overall- A bit heavier than I like, but still enjoyable.

Ambar rojiza, de escasa espuma, blanquecina. Translucida. Aroma frutal y tostado. En boca trago fácil, poco gas. Estupendo sabor que mezcla un tono general tostado con recuerdo de café, con notas de frutas rojas y amargor moderado. Buena ale. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Lovely deep colour, but too dark tasting and strong for my palate. Not for me at all. Overwhelming. 4/10.

Clear, really dark chestnut color with off white foam. Aromas of roasted malt, quite nice and strong at the same time. Palate was heavy, strong and full body. Tasted bit of alcohol, more on the stronger side, also malty and grainy but at the same time sweet, reminded me of some Lithuanian ales. Over all really good beer, really enjoyed it, definatly worth a try!
Dark brown with big cream head. Light sweet aroma of chocolate. Sweet malty taste with chocolate notes.

500ml Bottle This has a really thick and creamy mouth feel for a bottled beer. With molasses and coffee overtones, this black full bodied bottled beer may be a bit heavy for some, but at 6.3% it does its job and there are far worse beers out there - im a regular buyer.
One of the best looking bottled beers Ive seen in a glass, some tobacco notes in aroma greengage palms sherry lovely rich flavours would like to my hands on the cask version

Gravicask (PBF2013, Tuesday) as "Adnams Broadside Extra" at 6.5%
Super honey malts, lots of barley, full of malt, some marmite. At 6.x%, this is too weak this could be ramped up to 8-10% and turned into a proper barley wine. Heavyish palate, but only in a way that you want from an English Strong Ale. Finish is pleasantly resiny. Very tasty indeed. Drunk in pints, may leave you balance deficient.
Molasses & banana aroma, roasted malt & hops bitterness in taste, alcohol well hidden, bitter after taste, very balanced strong ale

500l Bottle from Sainsburys, New Mills, Derbyshire. 

Black beer with no head. Commercial description lists it as "rich in flavours of malt and hops" - its almost as if malt and hops are two of the primary ingredients of beer?! Give us a bit more credit please. I like Adnams as a rule but this is a middle of the road, vaguely smoky dark strong ale. Its more commendable characteristic is it will get you pissed.

Bottled 500ml. -from E.Leclerc Ljubljana. Dark amber coloured, medium sized pale beige head, caramel in the nose. Sweet malty, fruity, caramel , notes of dried fruits, hops and alcohol with malty finish. Pleasant brew.
On tap . @Cimmeria, Oviedo 30/07/2015Color caoba, espuma blanca, Aroma y sabores malta, caramelo.

500 ml bottle, pours ruby red, aroma is caramel, toffee malts, light roast, hazelnut, orange peel, almond, mince pie. Medium sweet, finish has some mild bitterness. Medium bodied, creamy texture, carbonation is soft to flat.

Fragancia dulce de aporte maltoso, con algunos perfiles tostados, recuerdos de frutas maduras, trazas de frutos secos, un punto acaramelado y un suave poso herbáceo.

En boca Entrada tremendamente maltosa, con adornos tostados, incluso intuyo algún destello ahumado, con una buena carga de meloso caramelo, perfiles de frutas maduras y un final amargo que remata felizmente el trago. El cuerpo es consistente, denso, y la carbonatación suave.

Excelente "strong ale" británica, con una base maltosa magnífica y un cuerpo voluptuoso que transmite un poderío extraordinario. Me fascina esta fórmula, su punto acaramelado y su perfecto balance herbáceo hace de ella un verdadero homenaje a la más pura tradición inglesa.
Bottle from a Suffolk Waitrose. Pours deep chestnut with an off white head. The taste is fruity malt with caramel, light spice and a little aniseed. Full flavoured and pretty tasty.

Oh yes, this proper glorious English ale, a powerhouse on the taste buds, this beer makes the heart sing, this is everything an ale should be sweet rich nose, beautiful colour, deep hoppy, fruity, if this beer was a book it would be A leather bound Lord of the rings in an old bookcase in a dark panelled room.....legend!

500ml : In a St Bernardus goblet . A r8 . Oh boy I used to really like this ten years ago when I was 23  and @ college . Despite this beer having somewhat of grandpha image going on -I cut my ale teeth on tepid brews  like this one. But i dont wanna be sentimental here . I think I had this too cold -the customary large rocky head was minimal here ...smoky ruby colour is tight ass bright and morphs into burnt purple . The nose is licorice , dark fruit like raisin , currant ,nutty almonds , Dundee cake ..Jamish boozy notes . quit warming , boozy , spicy , rich and bitter -thus i would say complex . the ale opens with rich chunky malt notes which give birth to coffee , licorice covered raisins , almost like an earthy soil texture. a dry bitterness is a welcome addition to the kinda syrupy flavours . On reflection I might be older and more jaded ,but this holds up well to this day .
500ml bottle poured dark & frothy the alcohol is barely noticeable the flavours are a fine blend malty hoppy fruity flavours bitter & a smooth finish great beer
Pours dark brown with tiny light brown head. Medium body, soft carbonation. Aroma of chocolate, pale malt, similar is taste. Surprisingly good beer, very enjoyable to drink.
Pours dark brown, white head. Roasted aroma, some alcohol taste, hops on finish balancing maltiness nicely.

Dark amber colour, with a thin head that leaves ring and lace. Aroma of chocolate, licorice, dark fruits, plums. Creamy, not much carbonation, medium body. Taste of chocolate, plums, dark fruits. Bitter rough finish.
Banana bread, ripe fruit, bubblegum, malty caramel. Really good aromas. Pours brown with basically no head. Malt, licorice, washed rind cheese. Very smooth and balanced.

500ml bottle pours a clear, deep reddish brown with off white large head reducing to cap. Aroma is intriguing, sweet estery bubblegum note, ripe fruits almost has a whiff of belgian yeast about it. Taste is bubblegum and ripe fruit again turning bitterish and slightly metallic. Low to medium carbonation, shortish drying finish. As good as I had remembered.

Bottle at home. Deep dark reddish to amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is quite full of licorice, ripe fruits, caramel and a hint of roasted malts. Flavor is quite bitter, sweet malts, but a rather dry finish. Solid body and smooth texture. Decent brew.
Dunkles braunrot, klar. Toffee, Karamell, schmeckt stark, würzig, langer bitterer Abgang. Hopfen: First Gold.

Pours dark mahogany, frothy tan head.
Aroma is dandelion, iron, coffee, cocoa, dried cranberries.
Creamy, low carbonation, oily. Good balance between sour, metallic and bitter flavours. Pleasant bitter ending.
Complex amber leading to an earthinesswith biscuit and dry spice. Fullish body. Bit of a classic.

Pint bottle into pint glass. Strong spicy malt nose, alcohol is noticeable. Ruby red beer with large tan head. Taste is burnt toffee followed by a little bitterness. Alcohol notes are present throughout. Ideal after-dinner beer.
50cl bottle from Aldi - pours dark amber with off white head, aroma of fruit cake, dried fruits. Taste - malt, fruit cake. Pretty good

Raspberry and malt aroma. Body is a deep ruby with a thin off white head. Biscuit and sweet raspberry taste balance with a moderate dose of bitterness. Has a bold presence but has a enough sweet malt as to not scare anyone off.
Aromas of Fake fruit flavoring. raspberry. Fairly sweet. Quite disappointing overall. Looks good though.

Nuts and toasty, even wooden, notes flavor, watery but with a notable body, easy to drink but highly enjoyable. A very remarkable sample of a modern English strong ales, and probably the best Adnams brewjob.

50cl Bottle from Co-operative. Clear ruby-brown colour, beige head. Aroma of fig bread, dates, earth, quite sweet, nuts, dark fruits, malty. Flavour is medium sweet, malty, figs, fig bread, dark fruits, light earthy bitter finish, some marmalade. Medium bodied. OK.

Pint bottle purchased from Lifesource Natural Grocer Salem OR
$4.99
Dark amber coloured ale with a small,bubbly tan head.
Great typical English malt and hop aromas. Hay,nuts,leafy and earthy very nice.
Balanced taste..interesting and with a strong light chocolate finish.
Great smooth mouthfeel.
Good traditional ale...excellent stuff.
500ml bottle at home. Pours a deep ruby colour with a white lingering head. Toffee aroma with hints of vanilla. Taste is burnt caramel, vanilla and hints of liquorice, and a nicely bitter aftertaste

Theres an acrid metallic quality running through this which spoils what otherwise would have be been ok. Its in the sweet/ bitterness, but way over egged. Decent flavours around it - soft dark fruits and reasonable balance otherwise.

50cl bottle from Tesco, consumed on 24/02/15. Pours dark brown with a thick tan coloured head. Full bodied. Aroma of malt and fruit. Flavours of malt, plum and figs - bitter but sweetness of molasses, chocolate and caramel. A full bodied strong English ale.

Bottle. Big, tan and frothy head, not very lasting. It will leave a very sligth lacing. Colour is mahogany with reddish hues. Aroma is toasted malt, fuity (plum) and hop tinge. Taste is toasted malt sweetness at attack (molasses), then fruity (plum) and roasted caramel dry bitternes at the end. Full body medium, oily. A balanced strong english ale. Very good.
Dark Bottle, pours dark caramel with a nice amber colored head. Scent is medium chocolatey. Medium density, chocolate notes throughout. Smooth finish. Great.

Bottle, 0.50l. Clear amber brown color with thin creamy off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, toffee, candy sugar, grass and dried fruits. Taste starts with sweet caramel and toffee, follows by mild and refreshing fruitiness, slightly roasty with warming mouthfeel and medium bitter finish. Medium body, syrupy texture and average carbonation in palate. Smooth and complex ale...

Heavy plummy figsy slight seet malty nose. Quite fruity, dadey actually. Full bodied, bit heavy. Dades, malty smooth breadyness, dark fruity finish. Flavourful english stronger ale. Real flavourful, but bit too overpowering to be super great.-- bb
Great beer! Thick, sweet and rich flavour With a good bitter finish. Great price and easily available in Australia. Best drunk when its cool and not cold.

Bottle. Clear dark amber body with medium white head. Aroma has caramel character, toffee, malty. Taste has noble bitterness, caramel sweetness, light roasty astringency in the after taste. Body is full, medium carbonation.

Brown sugar, dried fruits, coffee and some chocolate. Dark brown with a red tint, off-white head. Medium sweet and medium bitter. Medium body with a soft carbonation. Overall a really nice and rich ESA, but ever so slightly thin in the mouth.

500ml bottle from Tesco. Pours dark red-brown, off-white head. Aromas of toffee, burnt sugar, something metallic. Taste is more of the same, metallic notes dominating. Hides the strength well, but too sweet for me.

500 ML bottle

Dark ruby color, long lasting light tan head. Fairly rocky looking head. Good strips of lacing. 
Nose is roast malts and lots of fruitcake. Orange, cherry and caramel. Nice. 
Taste is very woody. Slightly faded orange peel, red cherry, toffee, and roast malts. Late wooded hop bite. 
Bottle is near expiration so the palate is a bit dulled. Very earthy and woody. Long lasting fruit and wood finish makes up for the front. Solid beer

Bottle kindly shared by Miro. Amber color with medium white head. Caramel, malt, some fruits in aroma, candies. Taste starts sweet malty with caramel, light roasted notes, followed by nice long hoppy bitterness. Good.

Bottle. Aroma metallic, lightstruck (whence the fuck? But here it is), light caramel malt and herbal nettle hoppiness. Conflicting. Clear amber-brown colour. Taste is initially watery, then astringency hits in, grainy, light simple caramel. Overall off and unpleasant. I do not like this.
Bottle shared by Cuso, many thanks pours dark amber color, lightly beige head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, bit hoppy. Taste starts sweet, lot of caramel, malt, candy, with nice bitter finish.
Bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts spicy caramel and fruits flavor malts fruits caramel spicy red fruits and some hops in the aftertaste
Dark ruby red, mildly carbonated. Plenty of flavour and a fair bit of punch. Reminds me a bit of Hobgoblin.

Deep brown with a ruby tint and a disappearing tan head. Deep smell of malt and soft roast with black current, nut, dates and liquorice. Sweet toasts of malt fills the mouth with a berry black current, soft roast, caramel and woody centre and a grassy hop bitterness finish. Very nice and full of rich flavour.

Bottle - average size foamy head, dark Amber color, sweet caramel malty aroma and flavor, mild hop balance, me nutty notes, pretty good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Lovely dark colour, bottle poured, off white head, great taste, mild hoppy taste with A good after taste for a strongish ale.
Bottle. Pours a deep amber colour with off-white head. Malty aroma with honey / treacle coming through. Lovely balanced sweet and bitter aftertaste.

This was a 500 ml. bottle and poured a red amber with a beige head. Nose of fruit and roasted malts. Medium in body and creamy in the mouth. Flavor is rich with fruit. The finish is bitter and flavorful. Nice in every way.

A dark reddish brown with a creamy head. Malty aromas, and a taste of malt and treacle. Rather sweet toffee-ish flavours followed by a strong, grassy bitterness from the hops. A good English bitter, but just a little too much malty sweetness for my taste.
Treacle nose with a vinegary overtone. Clear rust, thin yellow head, good lace. Rich toffee flavor, a little ashy. Grassy and leafy at midpalate. Subtle smoke finish. Medium body.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 50cl bottle at home. It pours a deep amber colour with a decent beige head that lasts. Aroma has a very sweet malts note, almonds and other kinds of nuts, dark fruits and some citrus from the hops. Taste has some pronounced caramel malts, toffee, raisins, some biscuity feeling and some bitterness from the citrus flavor. It has a medium body, decent carbonation, a little alcohol warmth and a dry finish. This is actually a good English strong Ale. Very solid and strong in flavor. I would drink it again.

Vierte color ámbar muy oscuro-rubí con abundante cabeza de espuma beige de retención media, en nariz aromas a caramelo, frutos secos, cacao y café, en boca entrada media y maltosa con amargor muy ligero que se acentúa en el pos gusto, notas a malta tostada; cuerpo y carbónico medios en una buena y fácil de beber red ale inglesa; es mejor saborearla en trago corto ya que aunque el alcohol está bien integrado el medio litro se acaba sintiendo.
Bottle from waitrose. Brown ale with a stodgy creamy head. Aroma is strong malty flavour. Malty taste with some alcohol warmth, good bitterness. Prickly carbonation medium body. Good.

hmm. bought this a while ago and found it in a pile of bottles, bomber from hyvee, shared with chad, and hakes dr.. dark brown or red pour with think white head, malty aroma, taste is a bitterb beries, not a bad English strong, (clearly not my usual pic)

Tasted from 1 pt 9oz bottle into nonic pint glass. It poured a dark reddish brown color with some chill haze (not sure if it was bottle fermented) with thin but persistent off-white foam and good lacing. Strong bready, malty aroma with First Gold hops: earthy, woodsy, resiny, mildly citrusy (same strain used by St Peters Organic Ale) with exquisitely fruity ale yeast esters: plums, apricots, raisins, cranberries. No trace of the elevated alcohol percentage. Profoundly rich and complex malt sweetness: toast, toffee, raisin bread, fruitcake, creamy chocolate, plum syrup, figgy pudding. Medium body, moderate carbonation. Full, creamy, and "chewy" mouthfeel with a long-lasting tangy aftertaste which eventually finished fairly dry. A classic, memorable example of Strong English Ale, with distinctly English hops, malt-bill and yeast profile. Just awesome.

50cL bottle. Pours an amber brown with a frothy cream head. Smells of caramel, sugar, fresh bread (with a hint of yeast), and roasted malt with a light whiff of hops and fruit in the background. Full-bodied flavor: starts flavor intensive and coalesces into a dry and alcoholic finish. Tastes of roasted malt, caramel, bread, a slight bit of spice and a hint of banana bread with walnut amidst a substantial underlying bitterness and slight fruit character. Quite tasty. A welcome change from the typical English beer (mild bitter).

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a deep mahogony with a light, creamy brown head lazing atop. Lots of roasted malts on the nose with a hint of bitterness to finish it off. Toasted cereal malts all over the taste with a touch of dried apple in there. Mouth feel is quite thin and easy drinking. Pretty good

500 ml Bottle from Tesco, served cool. Little aroma, but some "10p mix up" in the initial taste. Clear rich ruby red with a thin off-white head. Sweetness balanced with a bitter bite on the back of the tongue. Full bodied, slightly sticky as befits a slow sipping fruity dessert ale, I can imagine this served with a good cheddar and fruit cake in the Yorkshire way as suggested on the bottle. Like most good beers, effective in the right context.
This is quite a warming beer, nice dark appearance and full of fruity, spicy tastes

Bottle. Pours with a light tan head, clearer amber orange color. Very malty, but catch some bitterness in the aroma, earthy, nutty.  Some darker fruit flavors come in, with again a touch of earthier hop bitterness and a touch of toffee.  Medium body, with OK carbonation. Not bad.

Appearance: Dark copper/ruby red, slightly hazy. Noticeable carbonation. Forms a generous, off-white, soapy head - good retention and lacing.

Smell: Generic ESB scent with slight toasted cereal malts and hints of red fruit. Noticeable skunky/oxidation scent as well - not extremely foul, quite subtle, and easy to block out.

Taste: It took a few swigs to get used to the palate on this beer. It started out quite sharp and tangy, but eventually smoothened out to a more traditional ESB role. Mild palate for the most part, especially the first half. Theres slight toasted cereal malts and a surprisingly creamy texture and flavor. The second half is lightly bitter with a quick sour tang taste that leaves as quickly as it arrives. As the beer warms it becomes more fruity with red apple notes. Not a dry beer by any means, though. Not the tastiest palate in the world, and as a pub-style ale it works - nothing more, nothing less.

Drinkability: Perfectly medium-bodied in weight and density. Soft, somewhat cold mouthfeel that never dries out. Actually becomes more refreshing as it warms as the flavors begin to mature. The 6.3% ABV seems right on the money, although I could imagine sessioning this beer no problem - especially with pub fare.

Overall, not the best ESB on the market as it seems to have a few kinks to work out. But it is a solid performer in the end. I think this particular beer might be for more refined tastes than mass audiences, though.

dark red-brown, with caramely with resin hops, malt, clove, and raisiny aroma, clear with foamy head. full bodied with creamy sticky finish, lively carbonation and long finish. nice.

Originally rated January 2009. Purchased at the LCBO a while ago, but has a best before date on the neck, 11 JUN 09, so I am ok. Good strong scent at first, but disappears quickly, leaving only a little hop. Other things found in the taste as well, are dark fruits (raisins), roasted and caramel malts and burnt wood in the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is not as heavy as expected, almost thin and watery. Goes down easy and refreshing (weird for an English strong ale).
Good aroma light from fruit. Ruby amber color with a decent beige head. Flavors are fruit and toffee.malt, Good bitter balance.
Hazy red brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty, fruity and hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Finish is bitter as well. 041104

From a 500ml bottle on 12/12/2010. Has a quite modest though pleasant aroma of malt and citrus hops, which doesnt properly hint at experience to come. This is a very nice beer. Quite flavorful, but so drinkable. Good example of the complexity that ale has. Yummy. Serving: Bottle

12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy, dark brown colored body with a thin, brownish tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is fruity with lots of caramel malts. There is a hint of spicy hop that presents itself more than the aroma, but this is still all about the fruity malts. Lots of caramel with a big date taste and salt. There is a light roasty earth behind the malt that blends with the spice hint nicely to balance the rich and fruity malts. Some more apple-berry before this finishes with lots of rich, fruity malts along with a light, salty bitterness and some earthy roast that leaves a fairly lengthy aftertaste. Fairly bold for a sessionable English beer.

First taste is smooth nd malty flavouted with additional flavours of menthol, honey and roasty malts. Finish is slightly smokey witht the sweet malt flavour lingering.

Bouteille 500ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur brune-rouge foncée et claire. Nez fruité (prunes, moyen de raisins, traces de dates et de pommes), de malt rôti légèrement terreux, moyen de houblon floral aux notes herbeuses, léger de caramel toffee et avec des traces dalcool et de mélasse. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-bas et une texture très légèrement crémeuse. Goût fruité (prunes, léger de raisins aux faibles notes vineuses, traces de pommes rouges et de cerises) accompagné de notes de gâteau de fruits séchés et des traces de tabac lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt rôti et légèrement terreux avec des notes de caramel toffee et des traces de mélasse. Parallèlement, lon retrouve une moyenne-légère amertume de houblon floral (notes herbeuses) jusquen finale où lon retrouve également un très léger goût dalcool et des traces de noix. Post-goût moyen et un peu sec, léger-moyen amer de rôti doux, léger de houblon floral (notes terreuses) avec des notes fruitées (pelures de prunes, notes de moût de raisins).

Full body with a lasting finish.  Quite nice - very refreshing for a stronger beer.

I thought the aroma had some fruity ester that could have lead tom something interesting but the taste couldnt really match up with the rest -not bad overall but I wont seek this again necessarily.

Excellent winter ale. Warming, bitter, and properly British in style. Beautiful dark appearance too. Did not disappoint.

500 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with small tan head.  Nose of dark fruit, hint of alcohol and light roast.  Taste starts slightly watery but gives way to lingering sweet, dark fruit and alcohol sensation.  Ok, but didnt love it.

Draft at Flying Barrell in Göteborg, 2008-12-09 (before the hockey game)
AP: red/brown, medium high white head. AR: roasted malt, hints of red fruit F: roasted malt, hints of red fruit, medium bitterness

Bottle from Market of Choice. Poured a light chestnut brown with a mild tan head. Aroma was sweet chocolate, yeast, caramel malt. Flavor very caramel malty with a distinct nuttiness and some raisin flavor. Pretty tasty, and I love the label design on this one.

Bottle. Creamy off-whitye good mostly lasting head. Dark amber colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Long nice heavy bitter finish. Oily palate. Excellent beer.

Bottle.  Brown pour.  Light colored head.  Fruity aroma, raisins, port, caramel and some lightly oxidized smell.  Flavor is nice, round and malty with raisins, fruit, caramel and maybe a hint of oxidation, but not enough to hurt the beer. Pretty nice brew.

Pours a dark reddish brown with two fingers of frothy ecru head and patchy lace. The nose is round fruity and roasty malt, like dark bread with light molasses, figs and lightly peppery hops. On the light side of medium-bodied it features fine carbonation and a lightly spicy, bitter-hopped finish. It also has a touch of cardboard-y oxidation, but I have no idea of when this bottle was packaged. Sweet malt with notes of fig, dark bread, faint molasses, pepper and light cardboard. This is an interesting enough beer, I just wonder if this particular bottle was a bit past its prime.

The flavor contains darkly roasted caramel and cooked apple.  The flavors are strong, but are melded together well.  This beer is balalnced and solid with a soft, mellow mouthfeel. 
1 pint .9 fl. oz. bottle (Alc 6% Vol / Best Before 20 Nov 07 / 6233 1868) from Jungle Jims International Market in Fairfield, Ohio.  Rating #438 for this beer.

Sweet but more dry and bitter towards the end. Just a bit too much alcohol and medicinal bitterness in the finish.

Good one (06.VII.09).
Bottles from Waitrose. Brown/Red with an off white head. Very morish bottled ale with plenty of hops to balance the sweel malty back bone. A fair bit stronger than the cask version but quite similar.

500 ml bottle. Clear, reddish amber body with a fine off-white head. Aroma is malt, caramel and overripe fruit. Flavor is sweet, light roasted malt, ripe fruit, grassy hop and some warming alcohol. Really nice indeed.

(Bottle from Co-op, Long Stratton) Poured a very dark red with a huge fluffy off white head that resembled honeycomb a bit. Lasted for ages. Aroma of rich malt with big fruit, cherries and brown sugar. Taste a sweet fruity maltiness with biscuit and caramel hints. A bit bready with a full bodied flavour. a500 ml bottle from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. OC11/08.

Aroma:  Fruity, some tree fruits, some dark dried fruits, apples cherries, apricots, raisins, lightly spicy, a bit of brown sugar.

Flavour is fruits and some warming alcohol. But the best part is the complexity of this brew. Very nice.

pours a dark amber/brown with a thin but persistent  tan head with nice lacing..

Pretty Good.
Bottle. Pours a  deep redish color, big creamy head. Fruity malty aroma with a peace of hops. Nice bitter taste, and a sweet finish.

500ml Bottle: Pours caramel orange and cloudy with a top notch beige head that laces the glass very nicely.  Strong sweet malts, burnt sugar, and Christmas cake fruits in the aroma, very pleasing.  The taste initially hits with some spicy, sweet malts - seems like cinnamon, plums, butter, and caramel sugar.  A quick hit of hops bitters things down until the caramel comes through strong in the finish.  I actually quite enjoyed this one, very good.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, best before 11 JUN 2009, purchased at the LCBO on October 4 2008, savoured on November 23 2008; eye: burnt orange, hazy, no effervescence, beige head that turns into a tiny ring, some lacing; nose: lots of caramelized malt, good presence of bittering hops, candied fruits; mouth: caramelized malt, candied fruits, hops, finale in caramelized malt with a good presence of hops, mild astringency,  not much carbonation, mildly sweet and bitter, medium body; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, meilleure avant 11 juin 2009, achetée à la LCBO, savourée le 24 novembre 2008; il : orange brûlée, voilée, pas d’effervescence, mousse beige qui se transforme en un petit anneau, un peu de dentelle; nez : beaucoup de malt caramélisé, bonne présence de houblon amérisant, fruits confits; bouche : malt caramélisé, fruits confits, houblon, finale en malt caramélisé avec une bonne présence de houblon, astringence moyenne, peu carbonatée, moyennement amère et sucrée, corps moyen, riche; en résumé : bien
Wonderful aroma and flavour.  Beautiful colour.  Glad this has been brought to Ontario.

Pours a hazy deep brown bordering on burgundy with a creamy 2 finger tan head.  Lots of lacing.  If nothing else, so far, it’s beautiful to look at.  Smell is faint, a little bit of spicyness actually.  A little bit more roasted malts than caramel malts, and a tiny bit of hop bitterness.  Nice smell, but a bit too faint.  Flavour is nice, some faint dark fruits, and tiny bit of hop bitterness.  Some nice strong malt flavours there too.  Carbonation is low, but nice for the style, and it’s pretty chewy.  Very nice beer.

Bottle. Nice dark amber colour with a moderate lingering white head. Fruity nutty aromas. Quite sweet on the palate but finishes with a nice dry bitterness. More sessionable than its alcohol content suggests.. A fine English strong ale.

28/10/2008.
Bottle,Dark brown with a long lasting off white head,
Aroma’s of malt,mollases and vine fruits.
Leading to a rich flavour of sweet malt,christmas cake,and fruit.
Quite a pleasant subtle dry bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2013 500ml bottle from the LCBO
One of my new favouites
Tastes like an old fruit cake in liquid form an i like fruitcake:)

(Bottle 50 cl) Hazy reddish amber with an off-white head. Aroma of nuts and overripe fruit. Quite full-bodied with sweetish roasted malts, nuts and overripe fruit. Hints of wood and alcohol and a fairly bitter finish. Actually this mostly reminds me of a British style Old Ale. 290908

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 Bottled 50cl. It pours a beautiful beer which leaves a nice lacework. My nose was a bit blocked when sampling this one. Malty with some rasins showing up. Decent - but definetely nothing too exciting. Rerate pending.

Bottle - 500ml. Dark brown hazy body with a nice, lasting beige foamy head. Well balanced malty/hoppy aroma with oaky and toffee hints. Its hoppy taste is sharp and robust. It carries some roastiness and woodiness and hides the alcohol pretty well. Ends with a long and strong bitter finish. Excellent example of English Strong Ale.

Bottle. Eye-catching red/brown appearance. Fairly big aroma is dominated by molasses, plus accents of coffee, demerara, butter, roasted nuts and caramel. Toffee palate has an appropriate chewy mouthfeel. Nice molasses flavour and nutty finish. Very nice.

500ml Bottle, October 10, 2008. 
Poors dark brown/amber. Head is light. billowy and lasting with a nutty brown tinge. Aroma is dark fruit, particularly raisins. Malty, spices and hops are also present. Medium mouth feel. A strong bitterness complemented by caramel, raisin and cherry (probably some other "Christmas fruits" I am not identifying). Finishes nice and hoppy!

500 ml bottle, courtesy of Sigmund.  Dark brownish amber colored. Tall fluffy head with a nice tan. Beautiful toffee-ish malt aroma with ripe berries, raisins and some herbal/peppery hop notes. Taste has a high malt level; straightforward, light sweet and caramellish. Dark fruits and berries, and a distinct, earthy bitterness in the backbone. Medium to full body. Chewy texture. Slight sourish-fruity, malty-bitter ending. Well-crafted and moreish.

Bottle from the LCBO. Pours a nutty and slightly hazy ruby-brown colour with a medium sized tan head. Aroma brings to mind the Christmas holidays, with notes of plum pudding, caramel and candied fruit, along with sweet toasted malt. Full mouthfeel, and a flavour that starts with the rich sweetness expected based on the aroma, but also has some lingering hops and a slight alcohol warmth in the finish to add a pleasantly bitter counterpoint. A really nice autumn/winter ale.

Bottle (500ml ). Pours a hazy amber-brown with a long lasting creamy off-white head. Aroma of earthy malt, slightly toasted, sweet fruit, floral hops, light chocolate and alcohol. Malty flavour with some alcohol coming through along with spices, dark fruit, caramel and a good amount of hops in the finish. Medium bodied. Sticky mouthfeel. Very good stuff, glad I have more.

Originally tasted at the Toronto festival of beer, my notes weren’t great so re-rating this evening: Appearance: Red/brown with a slight but determined head. Aroma: Malt and that particular hop I don’t overly like (satz??) however it seems quite fitting into this aroma. Flavour: Caramel, malt, toffee with a nice sticky honey finish. Great beer. Delighted we can get it here in Ontario.

Dark auburn with a nice tan head.  Semi-sweet aroma and a flavour that was malty with a tinge of sweetness.  Nice hoppy finish.

A damn good ale.  Full bodied yet easy drinking.
Great straightforward balanced dark ale with some nice body, cake spice, amd some resiny hops. Very easy to drink yet fairly substantial.

Deep auburn colour with a frothy almond-coloured head.  The nose is fresh and malty with hints of chocolate and raisin.  The body is deep and smooth with a heavy malt sweetness.  A lingering, nicely balanced hop bitterness permeates the finish.  One of the nicest ales I’ve had in some time.  The balance is something you don’t find often in dark American strong ales.

Had this on tap at The Plough in London on 12/31/07 in an Adnams pint glass. Amber color and 1 finger off white head. Toasted malts, hops and bitters to the nose. Malt, grass, hay and bitters at first followed by a the same with a strange astringent taste. Slightly watered down body. Decent at best. Went ok with fish & chips but couldn’t stand alone.
Rich reddish brown hue, thick lacey head. Caramel flavors. Alcohol. A little plain. Good not great.

Bottle @ Smokeless Joe. Dark brown amber with creamy tan head. Mellow, slightly hoppy aroma. Gentle coppery scents. Gentle soft, velvety mouthfeel. Sweet malty entry. Alcohol punch in background and finish, some hop to keep it going. Straightforward and tastes stronger than it is, easy to sip.

Thick, cloudy, strong and straightforward. Heavy, malty, not too sweet and has enough body to handle the alcohol. Woody, a bit of dark fruit, licorice and a bit of salt with a lingering bitterness at the back of the tongue. Pretty well-made, but a bit flat and uninteresting.
Dark amber colour with thick off white head. Good malty aroma with nice floral hops and stewed fruits. Flavour has malts and fruity bits great body.  Should have got two of these.
really nice bready aroma, some wicked english hops,a very very nice ale. gets better as it warms, wicked stuff

500 mL bottle.  (bb 11 June 09).  Copper brown with a beautiful beige head.  Aroma is candied fruit, prunes, wild berries, and toffee.  Flavour is sweetish malt, with a nice bitter finish.  Not nearly as complex as the aroma.  Body fills out as the beer warms.  Fairly heavily carbonated.  Not bad.

Bottle from the LCBO- Deep chestnut pour unleashed a frothy mocha cap leaving pretty spiderweb lace. The aroma that I was first greeted with was caramel and then molasses. Dark fruits (plum, prune) follow with a bit of char and fruitcake. Tastes of sweet fruitcake and sugary nutty malts. Prune and dark plum come in and add more sweetness which is semi balanced by some metallic hops. Problem is, I hate the taste of fruitcake. This is not really good.

(Bottle, Monks Cafe, Stockholm, 15 Sep 2008) Dark reddish brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty nose with dark fruit, wild berries, blood oranges and caramel. Malty, fruity taste with dark fruit, caramel, blood oranges and generous doses of earthy, orangey hops in a fairly bitter finish. Everything backed up by a solid, chewy malt foundation. Above medium body. Superb and warming beer.
One of the most nice tasting beers i’ve ever had a mixture of hops fruit and malt, it tastes quite sweet but every mouthful is good.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2008 500mL bottle from the LCBO. Pours a very dark ruby with a large beige head. Nice looking one. Aroma: Not a whole lot going on in the nose from this one. Some OK caramalt, maybe a hint of some herbal hops. Some toffee, almost like a good but muted Dopplebock. What is there is nice (it improves dramatically as it warms). Flavour: Starts out very nicely with a wave of sweet British malts, then flows well into some very dry hops, with a touch of alcohol and a very dry finish/aftertaste. I was surprised by the dry hop character to the flavour given the aroma. Medium mouthfeel with a tolerable level of carbonation for the style. Sticky and sweet fruity malt elements become more apparent in the aftertaste to add some decent complexity. Quite a tasty one, with some aspects I have never come across before in an ESA. Seems a lot stronger than 6.3% abv.

500 ml bottle - pours an absolutely beautiful buckwheat honey shade with a healthy, billowy tan head that lasts for the entire pint and leaves extraordinarily thick lacing.  Aroma fairly subdued at the beginning, but as the beer warms, some subtle aromas of prune juice, currants and plum jam come out, along with a bit of yeast, and some alcohol as well.  Flavour is where the beer really shines, with a complex bouquet of dark fruits mingling with a slightly woody hop presence and a hint of treacle.  Warming alcohol at the back of the throat.  A superb beer for these cooler days and nights.  A real treat to be getting back to these types after a long summer of lighter brews.

Picked this up at LCBO, and pretty happy I did. Similar to belhavens wee heavy in some ways but not quit as good. The aroma is pretty a straight forward malty English ale,  toffee, caramel, almond all the malty good stuff. The Flavour is a pretty strong reflection of that, lots of malty goodness to be had in this beer,  toffee, caramel, honey, almond, but with a surprising light bitterness at the end, works well in my opinion. The palate is pretty decent, creamy fizzy mouth feel, dry finish, really decent. Will buy this again, but between wee heavy and this, wee heavy still wins.

500 ml bottle from the LCBO. pours beautiful dark red with a rocky tan head that lingers and laces. the aroma is muted but what there is typically malt forward english ale. initially you think the flavours will be similar because they start off very malty but then there is a huge bitter finish. the finish really clashes with the rest of the brew. not bad but id rather a wellington iron duke if i feel like an ESA.
Smell of malt with a hint of coffee. mid brown with a good size off white head. Had a strong malty taste. Slight carbonation and was thick and full bodied.

500ml bottle 
6.3% ABV 
I tried this beer on August 1, 2008 at "Smokeless Joe’s" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a very dark brownish red, with a thin tan head.  The aroma was caramel malt, and wood.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied, creamy, and medium carbonated.  The flavour was caramel malt, some spice, and a little bit of hops.

Pours a dark reddish-brown, with a very large foamy head that stands up.  Smell is malty, sweet and toasty.  Taste is a bit dissapointing, burnt malt and some sort of soapiness in the background, not great in my opinion.

Appears an auburn/brown with a small tan head that dissipates in no time. The trademark caramel/toffee of the style is present with some fruit and nut nuances. Palate delivers more of the same with nutty malt dominating early to give way to some piney notes and medium hop bitterness rounding out the back palate.

Bottle sample, TFOB ’08.  Great malty aroma, lots of spice and some alcohol.  Taste follows, more chewy malt, strong ESB like hops and a roasty finish.  Dark orange/brown a good sized white head.  A nice sipper that tastes stronger than it is - cannot wait to get my hands on more of these.

Decent, almost all malt beer. Nice caramel nutty flavor to it. Kind of fruity as well with some dark fruit flavors. Not much for hops, but that is expected. Nothing really stands out, but it is a pretty drinkable beer overall.
50 cl bottle, bought at Tesco, Liverpool. Brown color, nice big beige head. Aroma is fruity. Flavor is fruity with malt, hints of hops, caramel sweetness and a bitter finish.
Lots of nutty, dark fruit, caramel aroma.  Tan head that fades but still covers the surface.    Nuts, figs, roasted flavors, and piney hops.  It is like a light barleywine.

(500 ml bottle from Tully’s) First pour is slightly hazy darkish auburn with a big four fingers of biege head. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, perhaps toffee and then some pine hoppiness when head finally recedes a bit. A good bit of the head sticks around. Last pour is much darker and cloudier. Mouthfeel is fairly thick, fairly smooth. Has a somewhat filtered look and mouthfeel despite the bit of cloudiness. Lacing is big and patchy. Flavor of caramel, toffee and vanilla light-medium sweet maltiness overlain by a medium bitterness which is also a bit piney. Reminds me a bit of an English barleywine, say Young’s Old Nick, but less strong, big (and less flavorful). Still pretty good but I wouldn’t go out of my way for it.

Bottle from Waitrose. Red with a decent off-white head. Fruity, nutty aroma marred by a tainted, boiled sweet edge. Flavour of sweet malt with plenty of red fruit, a touch of spice and a short bitter finish. Nothing like as good as the weaker, cask-conditioned version.
500ml bottle. Reddy brown, head faded fairly quick. Nice and bitter, hints of dark fruit. Not bad.

Rich aroma with malty base and sweet fruity overtones. Nice amber color, generous carbonation. You might like it on some days, but it can be too heavy on others.  (the problem is the slight stickiness which surrounds everything like a puffed chewing gum)

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 Appearance: Brown-red, good amount of head.
Aroma: Fruity.
Taste: Smooth and fruity.
Info: 500ml bottle, 31/8-2005, 7/300, 4/500

This is a classic .  Hard to find now but one of the last in my stock. I only wish I could get this in cask. Hope it becomes available again. Dary ruby beer pours into a rocky head which subsides nicely. Inproves down to the bottom. Does not disappoint

The color is a cloudy brown with a redish tint and a thin head that fades rather quick. The nose is nice and malty with a nut finish, you can also detect some hop bitterness. The flavor is nice and sweet and has a minor tartness. You can taste some dark fruits but they are not overpowering. The finish is nice and bitter and that tartness stays with you for quite sometime. overall it is a nice and refreshing strong ale.

This is a decent alebit lighter take on the style than I normally go for, but it is definitely sessionable at best.  has some sweet fruitiness throughout with some rich caramel malt, with a hint of herbal hoppiness coming through in the finish.

Pours a cloudy amber colour with a creamy biege head that retains very well and leaves good lacing. A pleasing aroma of sweet malts, noble hops and an impression of beat sugars and fig. The flavour is rich in sweet malts, dark cherries, fennel and bitter hops with a coffee-like aftertaste. The body is full and the texture is creamy. The bitterness in the aftertaste is a bit astringent, but not so much so that it ruins the beer. I leaves a nice warming down in the cocckles.
Hazy brown with tiny off white head. Sweet fruity with roasted malt, caramel and liquerice. Mild hoppy finish.

Beautiful mahogany colour with a tight, thin white head. Aromas of dry german hops, yeast. Flavours of dark malt, a bit roasty and cherries with a dry spicy quality after the sweetness. This beer to me really tastes brings belgian, german and english influence togather. Its nice.

500 ml. bottle. Strong aromas of light stone fruit and lightly roasted malt. Rich ruby amber color with a decent beige head. Near full in body with creamy carbonation. Flavors are darker fruit, lighter fruit, caramel/toffee malt, and enough floral bitter to really balance. Finish is tending towards dry, and the bitter builds a bit over time. It is really good to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2009 [500ml bottle from Sainsburys, Reading] 9/3/2008: Coffee, dundee cake, a well balanced bitterness. Not huge depth, but a pleasant drink - this is how dark English beer should taste (but with a killer strength in this the bottled version!). Leaves a nice warm fuzzy glow! Re-rate 31/12/2008: As above, with some orange, spice and plenty of malt too. Very slight carbonation is about right for the style. Still felt more drunk on this than on other 6% beers for some reason!

50 cL bottle. Deep amber/brown, hazy and with a lacing tan head. Dense malt and fruit aroma. Flavour starts fruity and sweet. Goes into a spiced malt/hops dense flavour followed by a more bitterhops flavour. Spiced finish.
Had at Smokeless Joes, Amber color decent foam, nose is weak some malt. Flavor i get is malt some alcohol and a decent hop finish. quite nice actually

Bottle at Smokeless Joe 500 ml 
Appearance: Pours as clean, darker shade of amber with premium, thick tanned top. Nose : Fresh, soft hop character , light fruit side with twig , sweet malts add aromas balance.  Flavor/Palate : Medium bodied ale , top clean bitter British hops , light brown with some earthy side. Alcohol strong was well build into formula. Sadly midlle of palate was a bit flat. Dough malt with hint of rye paired with bitter hop coat of alcohol.
A good UK beer representative. The aroma contains the malt and the hops and it is acceptable.  Very drinkable, clean and refreshing lovely biitterness.At Smokeless.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2008 Pours dark brown with big off-white head. Lots of lacings.
Molasses, dry bitter hops, good mouthfeel.
Overall a good low carbonation British Ale.

Reddish brown with a dense and beautiful head. Bitter berry-like aroma and explosive flavours of nuts, chocoalte, caramel, toffee, black currants and cherries. Nice bitter ending and overall a lovely strong ale. 

.
Complex mixture of competing flavours and textures.  Beautifully put together.  Got better as it warmed up.  Good beer.

Copper-brown, opal, cramy tan head.
Rich malty, toasty, caramel aroma
Dry, hoppy taste.  Some bitterness quickly fading.
Carbonation spiciness, somewhat syrupy.
Yellow brown good head,very misty ale.Aroma toasted sugar,hops,flavour baked beans and ham smokey taste,fruit,hops,malt,caramel,brown sugar,finish bitter and spicey.

Pours a dark hazy brown color with thin head.  Aroma is very fruity with noses of dark fruit, apple and rich caramel.  Taste is apple and dark fruit up front and a little bit of red grape in the finish.  This ale is full bodied with mild carbonation and a chewy finish.  Very complex and pretty enjoyable, although its not one Id drink regularly.
Bottle pours a rich dark amber with a very thin head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Similar taste with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Overall a very nice English ale.

12 ounce bottle. Nearly opaque dark drown was a slight orange tinge. Nice head. Creamy beer -- softly carbonated -- with a rich flavor. Sure, theres some malty dark fruit/raisin sweetness, but it definitely has a hop bite to it, and buttery yeast as well. As it warms, I detect some citrus. Theres really a lot going on.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 Bottle (500ml). Poured opaque with ruby highlights and a tanned head which was mostly lasting. Aroma was of sweet blackberries and cranberries with some dark malts and molasses (light). Flavor was a blend of toffee and coffee with dark malts, dark chocolate, a subtle fruitiness; blackberries, raisins, plums and a great lingering bitterness. Full bodied with soft carbonation, chewy texture, syrupy mouthfeel and a long finish.
Bottle: Pours a dull murky brown with a large head.Taste is sweet with a hint of cherry and caramel. Palate is relatively thin.Smells of Sink water.

May 2006 - Thanks to eaglefan538 for this one.  Beer poured with nice looking head which vanished in the time it took me to walk to the next room and back.  The aroma was buttery, fruity and a little metallic...woulda scored higher if not for metallic aroma which was unpleasant.  Flavor was buttery sour, caramel and toffee...with a perfect level of bittering.  Mouthfeel was sticky and carbonated just right.  This was a nice beer.  I like these English ales!
Bottle.  Pours a clear bownish amber color wityh almost no head.  Average lacing. Malty and hoppy aroma with some caramel present.  I expected it to be "stronger."  But a decent beer nonetheless.

Bottle from Shigadeyo. Thanks butthole. Dark amber pour with a dense off white retentive head. Medium bodied, without the wateriness of the cask version. Aroma of caramel and wet malt grains. Initial flavor has a blend of toffee and caramel, with just a hint of nuts. This is countered by a soft spicy and herbal hop middle. More bitterness on the finish compared to the cask, and perhaps more tea notes as well. While this has a tad more heft, I found the cask more enjoyable as it was fresh and smoother on the finish. Pasteurization takes away some of the qualities I like in  this beer. However, this bottles much better than many other British beers.
Bottle at parents home. bread, brown, aminimal head, medium bitterness, average carbonation, medium body,

[784-20071028] 500mL (w/ jerc, tuqueboy). Grainy beer yeast aroma. Clear, dark red brown body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Citrus bitter bite flavour has a little grainy grass. Medium body is bitter initially. Nice bitter.
Pours a dark red with off white head. The aroma is full of sweet malt notes. Flavor has some berry flavor along with some bitterness. Nice finish.

Very nice indeed. 
Pours a deep deep ruby with a large foamy, lasting thick rich head. Rich is the word for it indeed. What a looker. Nice deep raisiny, malty fruity intense aroma.
Nice mouthfeel. Halfway through the pint and it a lovely and warming. Head still thick and foamy. mmmmm.
Tastes so rich and sweet malts.

Bottle. Ruby red colour, slightly hazy. Leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt, fruit cake and berries. Flavour is similar and the palate is rich and sweet. Quite a different drink from the cask version - its interesting to see the previous rater mentioning Youngs Old Nick - likewise I found this tasted like a weaker/milder version of a barley wine. I think I prefer the cask version, which is a good session drink for winter. If Im going to go for a strong bottled ale, Ill go for a proper barley wine or a Belgian Christmas ale.

Thanks to Shigadeyo for this one. Pours a murky dark red/brown and has a small but lasting head. Aroma is rich malts, ripened fruits, ashy hints, mild licorice. Flavors of sweet candied malts and fruits, light oaky hints, molasses. Sort of reminded me of a milder Youngs Old Nick. Lightly dry and bitter in the finish. I liked this one alot. Thanks again Craig for this nice suprise.
Brown, malty rich, heartwarming, bangers and mash style bitter.....makes me want to wear a paded elbow sportscoat.
Pours brown but has a fruity berry-like flavor amongst the malts in this chewy mix.

Courtesy Degarth. Root beer or cola looking body, lighter brown edges. Tan head, about a finger thick, fairly lasting. Not much, if any lacing. Fades into a layer of bubbles that stay atop the liquid throughout. Plums, tropical fruits, malts, spices and some phenols. Tastes pretty similar, but the alcohol hints drop out. Tons of sweet malts and a slight bitterness. Medium bodied, low carbonation. Finish is malts, dark fruits and spice. Lingers on the tongue and in the back of the throat for quite a while.

October 2007. Bottle shared by Mabel, brought back from England. Red-brown body with a modest head. Earthy malt throughout with a pleasant balancing bitterness that increases in the finish. Notes of caramel in the malt. Average palate. Very decent English ale.

Bottle brought directly to me by someone close to me while they were on holiday in London. A dark pour, nice malty, dark fruity aroma. Sweet, complex flavors of berries, currants, caramel, wood - cant find much in the way of hops other than a supporting bitterness. Round mouth feel, finishes clean. A very well done brew.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2008 From a 500 ml bottle presented to me by my lovely girlfriend Nancy - This brew pours a brown, fizzy brew with a very, very light tan head of foam and a weak, malty aroma. Tastewise, its a fine example of an English Strong Ale, with a sort of "brown ale EXTREME" character.

Thanks to kenb for the trade. Pours a mostly translucent ruby amber with a nice creamy off white lacing head.  Aroma of cherry, sweet malts, toffee, some citrus, other mixed fruits and a touch of hops.  Flavor of toffee, some toasted malts, a touch of hop bitterness, some citrus and a tad bit thin.
Well balanced medium-bodied, with even hops and bitterness. Although slightly watery it is easy on the palate and the soothing malts help it go down.

bottle from BOM club.  overall a very nice beer.  The 1/4" head lasted through most of the beer.  Aroma lacking in strength a bit.  Pours a deep red/amber.  Wonderful aftertaste with a nice long finish.  Caramel and malts are prevalent.  Lighter body than I would like... pleasantly surprised with this one.

Poured a slightly hazy, ruddy brown with a short cap of tan head.. really liked the look of this one.  The aroma had a nice Maris Otter-y appeal with caramel and English toffee at the forefront.. also some darker fruits and herbs as it warmed up.. enjoyed it!  The flavor had toasty caramel and toffee at the core with warm dark fruits extending outward.. warm at the finish with supple malts and the right dosage of spices and herbal bitterness.  Medium-bodied with very nice balance on the palate.. warm, tasty finish.  Well-done!

UPDATED: APR 25, 2011 500ml bottle. Poured a deep, clear mahogany red with a medium, lasting beige head. Rich red fruits, light tobacco & cakey roasty malt aromas. On the palate its sweet & fruit-forward with decent rich cakey malts, a bit of dry choc and a roasty-ish finish. Medium body, a bit empty in the mid palate with medium carbonation and a bittersweet finish.

Pours a deep red copper with a medium white head. Aroma features warm earthy almonds, a tangy english hop note, and a sweet fruit ester that is hard to put a finger on, I cant argue with the official line that its conserved fruit. On the palate there is sweet malt, nuts, almonds again , a touch of warming alcohol fruity  hop flavour a \nd finally a firm bitter finish. Wow.
Nose of malt, fruit and hops. Pours dark chestnut colored beer. Some carbonation. Mouthfeel is smooth, with chewy malts. A nice hoppy dry finish. A good beer.
(Bottled) Dark brown, clear. Malty-earthy scent. Carbonated. Oily, sticky mouthfeel. Malty biscuits and some coffee in the mouth.

Bottle (500ml).  From Waitrose.  Poured clear, deep ruby-amber, with a solid, lasting foamy-creamy tan head.  As I had the cask version just the night before, this was very interesting for me - the aroma is fairly deep roast malt, apple and light prune, lushly grainy and enough dry floral hops to keep it from seeming overly sweet; some alcohol on the nose.  The taste - even roastier, the floral hops are losing the battle, but this is a lovely caramel/light molasses malt beer with nice cool weather spice in the finish - excellent taste, enough raisin character to almost seem vinous, or even mildly port-like.  Solid body, a little sticky, nice carbonation, and enough alcohol to remind you this is WAY stronger than the cask version - as quaffable as the cask is, I really prefer this in the bottle, pasteurized or not (shock:  I dont give much more than a micrometrical crap about pasteurization/non-pasteurization).  Good beer!

Bottle(6%) from Hi-Time Wine. Pour a nice hazy prune color. Nose is kind of sweet. Some licorice and mabe a hint of raisin. Lightly sweet roasty flavors. Quite malty. Some English hops in there as well. Smooth creamy mouthfeel.
Bottle:  Spiced aroma, some corriander and carmelized sugar notes; heavy bicuitiness with a tart finish. Quite good, actually.

dark rusty amber, whispy head, sweet carmel aroma, rich carmel malt flavor, just a hint of bitterness
