text:
Crystal clear, mahogany ale with a large, frothy, beige head. Good lacing. Good retention
The nose is of dates, toffee, light honey and dark, fruity esters.
Very well-balanced flavor. Brown sugar and caramel. Very well-bittered.
Full-bodied with a fizzy mouthfeel. Astringent, dry finish. Leaves the mouth feeling oily. Very nice!

Tight and slightly brown head sitting over a delightful reddish brown coloured beer.  A faint hop nose, but nothing of the malt.  First taste is of a slightly sweet brew, but within seconds, the bitterness comes to the fore, where it remains for the remainder of the glass.  No warming alcohol which could be reasonably expected in a 6.3% ABV beer.  Overall a nice enough drop, but skewed towards the bitterness which is not at all the way of typical English Ales.

Medium rocky tan head with some decent lacing. Beautiful, clear  brown/red hued brew. Fruity, malty nose. Medium body. Good clean malt flavors, some hints of chocolate malt and a nice fruityness. Dry finish with a bitter bite.
surprised me with a very tangy, burnt fruit bitterness. some raw sugar in the aroma with a vague farminess. doughy and chewy with a full, almost american hop surge in the finish. quality stuff
UPDATED: MAY 28, 2004 Draught version:  Average tasting English Ale.  Not bad , but nothing exciting either.
Has a fruity malt aroma and is almost the same colour as the label, with abig but short-lived head. Flavour has sweet caramel and malt changing to a roasted bitterness at the end. Pretty good.

Bottle:  The beer is a brown color with a hint of amber to it.  I had to try real hard to get some head out of it, and it dissapated right away.  Maybe some fruitiness to the nose.  Not much else.  The taste is mostly a medium maly sweetness.  I also get the taste of alcohol:  suprising since the beer is only 6.3%.  Maybe some bitterness at the end.  It is almost trying to be a barleywine, but it doesn't really impress at all.
(500 ml bottle) Poured dark, dark ruby red. Blackcurrant/chocolate aroma. Strong malt character, with an astringent finish. Not one for me.

This beer didn't do it for me. A lightly acidic aroma that made my nose hairs curl! Almost well balanced. Nice malt flavors that were overwhelmed by an unpleasant bitterness (hops I'm guessing). The sulfur in the flavor didn't go well either. Aside from that, it is probably a decent beer.

A lovely way to round off an evening in the pub.  A classic crimson-amber colour in the glass, although the head does dissipate rather too rapidly.  The taste and feel of the beer are both good with no unpleasant hanging aftertaste.  Difficult to have more than a couple of them though as it begins to feel a bit heavy and the maltiness begins to get to you but for a tipple to round off a session it's a great choice.

malty nose, wonderful dark red hue with an average sized head, traces of nuts, cherries and malts, full bodied with a great malty finish
A little beauty. A wonderful mellow taste with hints of nut and malt. A strong UK brew.
Top stuff, just the way I like it!  Smooth with a great balance. Has the hoppy bite yet not too bitter.  Quality.
Amber-red in color with a rocky head. Very smooth body with a mellow, nutty malt flavor.Surprising crisp, dry finish.Strong stuff

Re-rate: deep cherry brown colour, very nice lasting half inch head. aroma is of sweet toffee malt, with perhaps some berries. Palate is sweet then bitter (i.e malty, then hoppy). Toffee, berries, with some late tea/hop flavours, kind of sticky, but relatively smooth, dont like as much as the first time i had it, but still quite nice.

Hazy translucent deep red-brown under a large reasonable lasting yellow tan head. Faint woodiness, hops, and caramelly roasted malt aroma.  Stronger floral nectar and fruitiness on warming and glass swirl. Full smooth filling body with vague hint of stout palate. Start is strong bitter  sweet roasted malt, caramel and some evidence of hops. Other flavours include nuts, coffee, oak, honey and smoke. Mainly bitter with lighter sweeter finish and aftertaste. A most pleasant winter warmer.

(cask)nice dark strong ale.
beautuful dark nut brown with a light head.
sweet malty aroma but noticeable hoppiness.
the taste is full of sweet smoked flavors notes of chocolate, caramel  and bread.
warming stuff with a a hop bite that makes it a pleasure to sip.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2012 April, 2004 Pasteurised bottle.  Deeply gorgeous. [3.5]
May, 2012 500ml bottle from Sainsbury. A dark amber ale with molasses toffee bread impregnated with tobacco and rum. The whole rubbed with orange zest and finishing with a generous warmth. A lovely fireside ale - much richer and hearty than the 6.3% would suggest. Bloody spanking! [4.2]
Deep amber-brown; deeply chewy, sweet, with a touch of dryness in the finish.  I found toffee, sweet cherries, roses, brown sugar and an insistent earthiness.

dark brown, couldnt see thru it. very mouth-warming taste. thick malts, long lasting, very warm, bitterness.  When held up to the light, mine had a lot of floaties, but it doesnt indicate bottle conditioned.  Although this tastes very good, Im suspicious that Ive gotten an old bottle.
Large thick airy head with a slightly sweet yet hoppy aroma.  The taste and palate improves with the more you drink.  The taste is strongly hopped and cunningly bitter.  Not bad, not bad at all!!
I feel sorry for everyone who hasnt experienced this stuff on tap it is one hefty pint, full hoppy flavour and a lot of kick!

Kind of muddy looking, not much head, appearance is the least attractive aspect of this beer. Aroma is only a hint of what is to come. Full of flavor, sweetened coffee and some fruitiness, perhaps raisin. Lots of body, almost too thick. Dont know that Id care to have this on a hot summer day, but very nice on a cool day.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2003 Bottled. Ruby red/ brown, off white head that was shortlived and moderate condition. Some roast barley and earthy aromas. Malty in the mouth, bordering on barley wine syrupy sweetness. Finish  is sweet and malty

Big, richly fruity and hoppy ale, with a good balance. Not particularly beautiful or subtle, but gives a good hoppy kick. One of those beers that arent trying to taste of anything more than their ingredients: (crystal and amber) malt, (fuggles and goldings) hops, water. Kind of lovably stodgy, like Geoff Boycott.

Broadside is the srongest and most  gutsy of the Adnams easily available beers. Not often seen on draft outside the delightful Suffolk seaside town where its brewed, broadsides strenght and character mean two pints is just enough! Particularly pleasant in winter time, although its not specifically a winter brew.  Bottled tends to be a trifle gassy, but gorgeous nontheless. Do yourself a favour, rent a beach hut at Southwold, buy some fish and chips and curl up with a broadside or two. Wonderful.
